title: At close of business on 16 June 2021, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 28 April 2021?
preds: "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" policy
I have a feeling Fed may change their tune on inflation and interest rates in 2021, but not in next 3 weeks.

US Inflation rate is 2.62%.
Unemployment rate is 6.1% In my opinion, the Fed will keep the rate unchanged to boost the economy further and recover fully from the pandemic.

The Fed have noted that they will keep interest rates at the same level for the foreseeable future. However, I think movement in US Treasury Bond Yields and mounting chatter of increased inflation has a small change of nudging the Fed to slightly raise the funds rate. This is a very small possibility.
Adjusting towards 'same' and giving some more weight towards Higher than Lower given data available.

Powell refrained from specifying what a moderate overshooting of the inflation target means, but kept saying that the Fed now purposely remains behind the curve as they “need to see actual progress, not forecasted progress.” … But he made a small and potentially costly mistake by admitting to having to quantify what a moderately overshooting inflation rate means as soon as inflation overshoots the target. Powell said that “..we have resisted the temptation to try and quantify what that means, but when we are above target… we can do that” . This will leave stakes SUPER high ahead of inflation figures from April when the big inflationary effects start to kick in. After all, it is much easier to say that you will allow inflation to overshoot as long as you actually don’t overshoot, but once the overshooting kicks in, it will be much more difficult to sound as dovish.
https://corporate.nordea.com/article/64255/fomc-review-officially-behind-the-curve-and-proud-of-it Though this is just a view but a compelling one so turning a bit cautious with my forecast. For Future forecasts i think should look carefully at the inflation trends than the fed`s signals which can change with a lag
Powells words following the fed meeting this week show no sign of interest rates going higher before 2023. I see even less chance that they'll take rates below 0. Adjusting heavily towards "same"

https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU I assume this is what is referred to by the question. The rate has been consistently set at 0.25% since March 16, 2020. While I expect a robust recovery in the US aided by a strong vaccination program and stimulative government spending, the global economy will remain weak and we will not be back to full employment in the timeframe of the question.

Rate is (bare extreme circumstances) set at pre-announced meetings, next 3 of which take place at:
March 16-17*
April 27-28
June 15-16* I started of by calculate base rates for 
0) probability of further decline
1) probability of rate hike after it was cut, based on time passed since cut
2) what happens with rates 3 meetings after it was hiked 0) this seems extremely unlikely as its unprecedented.
i have not recently spent much time on this but 0.25 (and 0.00 for lower limit) are considered a lower bound
0% 1) rates have been flat since march.
I identified 27 earlier periods where rates where flat, ranging in length from 1 - 80+ (GFC) months. Month	Months since flat	Historical P
01/01/2021	11	23%
01/02/2021	12	19%
01/03/2021	13	18%
01/04/2021	14	17%
01/05/2021	15	15%
01/06/2021	16	10% Historically the probability that rates remain flat for 14 months (and thus are still at 0.25 in april) is 17%.
The probability of them still being flat in june is 10%, following the same logic.
So i'm thinking :
given that we were flat in january, what is probability of remaining flat in march, april and june?
so that 78%, 72% and 45%. 2) so what happens 1or 2 months (meetings realy, but ok) after a first hike? 1m after hike	
down	6%
same	51%
up	43%

2 m after hike	
down	13%
same	32%
up	56% So putting all this together i build scenario's with down/same/up (-1 0 1) for mar/april/june, taking into account that rates won't go below current level. M	A	J	P()
0	0	0	45%
0	0	1	28%
0	1	-1	0%
0	1	0	3%
0	1	1	2%
1	0	-1	1%

1	-1	0	1%
1	-1	1	0%
1	1	-1	1%
1	1	0	5%
1	1	1	4% If i combine these i get : Prob lower	10%
Prob same	58%
Prob higher	32% Subject ot vaccine roll out i would probably initially have put more weight on "same" (and took away from both lower and higher, because lower has no chances if there's not increase first).
So will adjust somewhat more to "same" and cut "lower" and "higher" by 5 and 10%points respectively.

Unemployment is too high to tighten by June, and they won't tighten because of inflation as they have a new inflation target with much more slack than the old one (they need to come the output gap before they start raising rates). When they tighten, it will be via their balance sheet first (ending QE) rather than higher rates. The balance sheet rather than the Fed Funds rate is the active variable in the near term.
With vaccinations the US economic activity should pick up. So the rates should be the same or higher.
Upward pressure mounting. Unlikely in this timeline, however.

Lower would mean 0% or negative rates that I do not see the US Fed dabbling with. Yellen as Fed Chair does not seem too keen on raising interest rates any time soon (or at least her rhetoric suggests). Past week's market fiasco with Gamestop/AMC/etc. may drive the conversation about saving/investing in low-interest markets but with COVID still a roaring disaster in the US I expect interest rates to stay as low as they are now for the next 6 months.

FOMC Meetings are scheduled for March 17th, April 28th, and June 16th [1] [2]:
March 17th futures: 99.9325
April 28th futures: 99.9325
June 16th futures: 99.9275 Lower would put us into NIRP territory. Unlikely but possible. By far most likely case is target rate stays at 0-25. [1] https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm
[2] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/stir/30-day-federal-fund.html
Because consensus of forecasters and experienced/good forecasters (see @SE_Meyer )
Powell cannot cover his shorts nor his longs!

I think it is more likely than not that the federal funds rate will be the same at close of business on June 16 as it will be close of business April 28.  Currently the federal funds rate range is low at 0%-.25%. The rate was lowered in March 2020 in response to the economic impact of Covid-19, and although the stock market rebounded quickly, unemployment remains high and inflation rates lower than you would expect in a healthy, growing economy. Because economic recovery from the pandemic is ongoing, I think the Fed will be reluctant to raise the upper limit of the federal funds rate range until we begin to see clearer signs of economic recovery. With entire economic sectors like hospitality and entertainment still struggling, I think economic recovery will remain slow until we move closer to herd immunity, which is unlikely to happen in 2021. The Fed has previously indicated an unwillingness to let the federal funds rate go negative. I think this is most likely to remain the case. Negative rates have the potential to disrupt banking and financial sectors, and their lackluster impact in Europe indicates that the disruption may not be worth it.
I think rates to borrow will remain the same throughout 2021.

With rates at a current consensus around 0%, it is unlikely any change will occur by summer.  There has been no indication of a desire for negative rates, and given the current turmoil in the securities market thanks to amateur investors, there is little desire to further fuel that volatility.  A rapid economic rebound by summer thanks to an abundance of COVID vaccines and continual deficit spending has the potential to induce inflationary pressures, although this likelihood is low given the recent history of low inflation and the anticipated lull in economic activity through at least the second quarter of 2021.

It's certainly not going any higher. They're not even thinking about thinking about thinking about that. I do think things will get bad enough eventually that they will go to negative interest rates, but not by April. First they will greatly ramp up the quantitative easing.

The Federal Reserve has held its target range for the federal funds rate the same since March 2020. At the most recent meeting the committee that decides the target range stated they intend to hold the current rate steady until at least 2023. During the last economic crisis in 2008, the target range for the federal funds rate held constant until December 2015. It is highly unlikely that there will be a sudden change in monetary policy within the next five months and it is even more unlikely that a change will occur between the April and June meetings. https://www.thebalance.com/current-federal-reserve-interest-rates-4770718
